quoteFirst: Nothing is Too Small to be Organized. In our country home, Caslon Farm, we have a model kitchen and by motion study we have cut down the motions our cook uses in making rice pudding from
quoteLast: , or, with raisins, eight. Organization! It used to take our nurse twenty-six minutes by stop watch to bathe our baby; now she does it in fourteen; we saved seven minutes just by using blotters instead of towels. Yes, Henry T.
title: Apes and Angels
author: Connell, Richard Edward, 1893-1949

quoteLast: , Bermuda time, climbed to ten thousand feet and leveled off. Almost immediately the crew saw an oil leak in the No. 1 engine and it was feathered.
title: The Hurricane Hunters
author: Tannehill, Ivan Ray, 1890-1959

quoteLast: On reaching home I went up to dress to my own room, which communicates with my wife’s by a stained oak door. Judge of my surprise to find it tenanted by a giraffe (_Tragelaphus Asiaticus_).
title: The Puppet Show of Memory
author: Baring, Maurice, 1874-1945

quoteFirst: The interior is composed of a single nave, two hundred feet long and from
quoteLast: ty feet wide. There are four chapels on one side and three on the other. At the east end of the church is a shallow five-sided apse, forming the Capilla Mayor.
title: Toledo: an historical and descriptive account of the "City of generations"
author: Calvert, Albert Frederick, 1872-1946

quoteFirst: The third phase, which lasted from
quoteLast: until 8.20 p.m., was fought generally at about 12,000 yards, though now and then the range came down to 9,000 yards. The Germans, fending us off with torpedo onslaughts, did their utmost to open out the ranges and used smoke screens to lessen what visibility the atmosphere permitted.
title:
The Silent Watchers
England's Navy during the Great War: What It Is, and What We Owe to It
author: Copplestone, Bennet, 1867-1932

quoteFirst: The first point essential to an understanding is that Jellicoe’s deployment was not complete until late in the afternoon,
title:
The Silent Watchers
England's Navy during the Great War: What It Is, and What We Owe to It
author: Copplestone, Bennet, 1867-1932

quoteFirst: The action between the battle fleets lasted intermittently from
quoteLast: to 8.20 P.M. at ranges between 9,000 and 12,000 yards, during which time the British Fleet made alterations of course from S.E. by E. to W. in the endeavour to close. The enemy constantly turned away and opened the range under cover of destroyer attacks and smoke screens as the effect of the British fire was felt, and the alterations, of course, had the effect of bringing the British Fleet (which commenced the action in a position of advantage on the bow of the enemy) to a quarterly bearing from the enemy battle line, but at the same time placed us between the enemy and his
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: The fire of _Marlborough_ (Captain George P. Ross) was particularly rapid and effective. This ship commenced at
quoteLast: by firing seven salvoes at a ship of the “Kaiser” class, then engaged a cruiser, and again a battleship, and at 6.54 she was hit by a torpedo and took up a considerable list to starboard, but re-opened at 7.3 P.M. at a cruiser and at 7.12 P.M. fired fourteen rapid salvoes at a ship of the “König” class, hitting her frequently until she turned out of the line.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: 14. The First Battle Squadron, which was in the rear on deployment, became engaged during deployment, the Vice-Admiral opening fire at
quoteLast: on a battleship of the “Kaiser” class. The centre squadron, which had previously been firing at an enemy light cruiser, opened fire at 6.30 P.M. on a battleship of the “König” class, and the van squadron commenced immediately afterwards.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935
